page.title: 01LANDSCAPE
page.content: LANDSCAPE - Brassington is an area of contrasts stretching from 750ft above sea level to 1150ft. It is an old mining village sheltered to the north and east by hills, to the west it is more open with views over the Staffordshire hills. A substratum of limestone under lies the area and charaterises the soil which is chiefly laid down in meadow and pasture. Longcliffe to the north is the southern edge of the Peak District National Park. Here the fields are divided into small plots surrounded by dry stone walls and very few trees. To the south trees and hedges divide the fields, thus making a marked contrast between the two areas. Some of the natural beauty is being restored to the hills by the removal and levelling of the heaps of waste left from the old lead mines.
